text:
Day one, review one: The Geek Way

It‚Äôs well articulated, it‚Äôs by an industry-adjacent person, and it‚Äôs pro tech. 

But it‚Äôs not going to surprise anyone already steeped in startup culture. 

It advises a four prong recipe for building a successful company culture:

- make data driven decisions 
- promote agency/ownership
- move fast
- be super open

If you‚Äôre looking at that and going ‚Äúhell yeah‚Äù then it‚Äôs safe to skip this one. 

But it‚Äôd be a good handbook for teaching newcomers and outsiders. And it‚Äôd make a great passive aggressive birthday gift for a cofounder who thinks his ‚ÄúSteve Jobs level product intuition‚Äù trumps your ‚ÄúAB testing data‚Äù

Four stars for its type, a solid 101 on healthy tech company culture

Day two: Cod 

It‚Äôs hard to credibly convey how compelling Kurlansky‚Äôs books are, given the seemingly dull subject matter. The prose is merely fair, but the research is  impeccable and he mixes colorful illustrative anecdotes in at the perfect pace.

My then 5yo never lost interest, which is strong testimony. Four stars for its type. 

His books on salt and onions are also worth reading. For the sake of calibration, I‚Äôd cite At Home and The Mother Tongue by Bill Bryson as five star examples of the class.

Day four: Master and Commander

One of the all time heavyweight champions of historical fiction. Bill Bryson calls it his favorite escapist reading. Keith Richards shouts it out at the end of his book Life.

There are a bunch of red flags on this book for me:
- this book is the first in a series of 20
- it‚Äôs a historical seafaring adventure
- it was written in the 60s but uses period language
- it‚Äôs laden with esoteric jargon

Given the red flags, I expected a cheap swashbuckling novel hiding its poor writing behind unfamiliar language. But the exact opposite is the case. The whole series is outstanding.

The prose is excellent, once you get your head into it. The character development is first rate and continues throughout the series. The stories are subtle and nuanced in a way you‚Äôd never expect from historical military fiction.

O‚ÄôBrian is the John Williams of his niche. You‚Äôd never mention them in the same breath as confirmed masters like Beethoven or Jane Austen, but we should.

Five stars easy

Day six: War by Sebastian Junger

My favorite war book of all time. 

I‚Äôve never been in a war or anywhere near one, so take it with a grain of salt. But you can‚Äôt talk about this book without praising its realism. At the very least, any civilian should be able to recognize a believably complicated picture of humanity‚Äôs relationship with war. 

Yeah, war‚Äôs bad and miserable of course. But for the young men standing behind the weapons and hoping the enemy bullets miss them, it‚Äôs also peerlessly exciting. 

The book is full of great characters, memorable scenes, captivating detail, excellent writing, and a surprising amount of comic relief. Fans of Sebastian Junger will recognize his familiar role of narrator/character taken to its pinnacle. 

There‚Äôs also a pair of great documentaries to go with it. 

If you only ever read one book about war, read this one. 

5/5 no notes

Day seven: Freedom by Sebastian Junger

Not his strongest work, but not bad. 

Explicitly, it‚Äôs a story of a weird, long hike he took with some friends interspersed with characteristically well researched and written information about, well‚Ä¶ freedom. 

It was most enjoyable for me as the implicit story of his midlife crisis. He was clearly in a weird place emotionally. I suspect he was processing some actual PTSD from the War days and also probably feeling a bit uncomfortable about having achieved such success on such a sensitive topic. You get the feeling he was trying to recreate the feeling of being part of a small, fiercely cohesive, tightly aligned group as a form of therapy. Or at least as a hit of his preferred drug. 

It‚Äôs a relatively weak point in his bibliography and I suggest Tribe instead as a direct comparable. And don‚Äôt go digging deep into the minor titles at all until you‚Äôve read the Perfect Storm and War. 

Three stars by Sebastian Junger standards.

Day eight: The Things They Carried 

This was my first reread since I was a teenager and I‚Äôm pleased to report that it holds up. The writing is excellent and the stories hit like one ton of bricks after another. 

Its posture towards war is right down the middle. Not as willing to address the special bonding or moments of excitement as War by Junger. But doesn‚Äôt treat it as a series of unmitigated miseries like All Quiet on the Western Front. 

It does a good job of looking fear and shame in the face, in the tradition of Red Badge of Courage. But it also has one of the best lines about courage ever written. To paraphrase: it‚Äôs a muscle you build, not a hoard you store up to draw down when you need it. 

This is tenth grade English teachers‚Äô favorite book to assign for good reason. Great writing, great storytelling, universally accessible. Five stars.

Day nine: The Ancient City

An incredible portrait of life in ancient times, centered around how early religion grew into early civic life. 

If you think about the Roman Empire every day and you haven‚Äôt read this yet, you should treat yourself. 

It‚Äôs so juicy and homey compared to the sanitized and streamlined histories of wars and large scale politics. 

I keep multiple copies in my house to give away so that I don‚Äôt end up losing my personal copy. 

The most vivid and human look at life in classical Greece and Rome. Pound for pound my favorite book on ancient times. 

Five stars. Keep the home fire burning ü´°

Day 11: The Age of Gold 

This was great fun. The writing is good, it‚Äôs packed with exciting adventure, and it‚Äôs got enough history to feel substantial.

More than I expected, a lot of it echoes the tech industry: the frenetic energy, SF as the center of the universe, cycles of boom and bust. Even the $10 cups of coffee. 

It‚Äôs the early history of California through the lens of gold prospecting, but it‚Äôs also a set of warnings about our own time. 

If you‚Äôre new to the Bay Area, I especially recommend reading this. Even if you‚Äôre not, it‚Äôs worth adding to your list. It‚Äôd make a great book for an international flight. If nothing else, it‚Äôll make you grateful that you don‚Äôt have to cross the Darien Gap on foot. 

Four stars for its type, but only because its type is so stacked.

Day 12: Dispatches 

A semi-cohesive collection of spectacular gonzo flavored Vietnam War semi-journalism. 

Chaotic neutral on the war book alignment chart. The author worked on the scripts for Apocalypse Now and Full Metal Jacket and this book has a lot of that energy. 

It also created lot of the vibe and a lot of the tropes that show up consistently in other Vietnam War movies. 

It‚Äôs heavy on absurdity and you constantly feel like anything could happen, but it never gets too disorienting. If you read it in a single sitting, you‚Äôd spend the next week talking like Dennis Hopper‚Äôs character from Apocalypse Now. 

Five stars. Definitive work

Day 15: When Breath Becomes Air

A neurosurgeon reflects on the meaning of life as he approaches death. What could be bad about that, right? Such poignant irony! Such perspective!

When I plucked this off of my wife‚Äôs section of the bookshelf, that‚Äôs what was running through my head.

‚ÄúGreat, I‚Äôll read it and then my wife and I can talk about it together!‚Äù

So I‚Äôm psyched. I love books about death. I love reading books by super smart people. I get settled in and start reading.

It quickly becomes clear to me that I‚Äôm reading a collection of essays, panicked diary entries, and dollar store philosophical ramblings. Apparently the editors, without a living author to work with, decided to just ship it as they found it.

If Kalanithi had made a miraculous recovery, he‚Äôd have reread this, realized that it‚Äôs sentimental hallmark movie slop, and tucked it in the drawer where it belongs.

I went to my wife to say all this. Her response: ‚ÄúOh yeah, never read it.‚Äù

Two stars. Don‚Äôt fall for it.

Day 17: The Jungle Book 

A series of fable-ish stories mostly populated by animal characters, including a bunch that don‚Äôt star Mowgli. 

The Mowgli stories are the best known for good reason. The Rikki-Tikki-Tavi story is the second strongest. The rest are good but not noteworthy. 

My 6yo and I both had a pretty tepid reaction to it. If you‚Äôre out of content to read with your kids, go for it. But here are some alternatives I‚Äôd recommend more strongly:

Better orphan story: The Graveyard Book

Better animal story: Watership Down

Better adventure: Treasure Island 

Better Kipling: Captains Courageous 

Four stars carried on Mowgli‚Äôs little man cub back

Day 18: The Magic Mountain 

A novel about time, illness, death, and the fight for the spirit of Europe. 

If you pick this up, you better be prepared to put your ass into it. Superficially, it‚Äôs ~1000 pages of the petty squabbles of affluent Europeans in a sanitorium. But it‚Äôs one of those books that professors love where actively decoding it transforms the experience. 

I read it primarily because Joseph Campbell treats it as a peer to Ulysses in Creative Mythology. It falls well short of that mark. 

You probably already know if you should read this. If you‚Äôre uncertain, read something else. 

I‚Äôm going to reject its classification as great modern literature and I‚Äôm still going to give it only three stars for its class. I did the interpretive work and it still fell flat for me. 

If you loved it, please reply to convince me that I‚Äôm a phillistine. Until then, I maintain that the only reason to profess fondness for it is to impress others who also think they‚Äôre supposed to like it.

Red Rising

Oppressed poor boy who‚Äôs Ackchyually Super Awsome sneaks into the rich kids‚Äô hunger games summer camp. He sees through the meta, crushes the game, and gets the girl, even though she‚Äôs not as good as his old ride or die poor girl.

The writing at the end is mediocre, which comes as a huge relief after the atrocious writing at the beginning. The author was apparently figuring out how to write in real time over the course of drafting the book. God awful prose, even by the most tolerant standards. 

The storytelling, as distinct from the language itself, is passable, if unimaginative. The character development is laughable. The thesis is exhausted, the tropes are threadbare, and the relationships are entirely implausible. 

Absolute slop, a waste of attention, almost no redeeming qualities. 

My 5yo loved it. 

Two stars, only because I have a soft spot for Battle Royale stories.

Chaos Monkeys

Our own @antonio tells the story of his journey from square job to startup job to founder to acquired by FAANG. Plus, a lot of personal life hijinks. 

The most important point is that he can actually write. He also knows the industry firsthand. 

The book does a good job of avoiding both vapid tech industry boosterism and groundless anti tech vitriol. 

In other words, it paints a fair, high res picture of our industry. That, plus its consistently irreverent humor, makes it a rare work indeed. 

Five stars for its class.

The Optimist

David Coggins tells a series of fishing stories. 

I read five books about fishing in 2024 and instead of rating them out of five stars I‚Äôm just going to rank them. They‚Äôre all passable if you‚Äôre into fly fishing.

Trout Bum
The Longest Silence
Lords of the Fly
The Optimist
The Believer 

I fished over 100 days in 2024, all with a fly rod. I don‚Äôt show it in this persona, but I am a hardcore fisherman. And if you have been following this series of reviews, you know I‚Äôm a hardcore reader. 

Fishing, especially fly fishing, has layers and layers of esoteric strata. David Coggins writes capably, but it‚Äôs clear that he‚Äôs essentially a wash ashore to the land of fishing. 

If you‚Äôre a filthy casual or if you fish with conventional tackle and you‚Äôre curious about fly fishing, this might be a better pick for you. For me, there were too many cases where his explicit assertions about dedication to fishing sounded dissonant against the implicit revelation that he‚Äôs not.

The Believer

David Coggins extends The Optimist by a few hundred pages. 

His writing is still good, and his devotion to fishing increased. 

But still, these are not great fishing devotionals. 

Even if you love fishing and have never surfed, read Barbarian Days instead of these.

The Secret History of Christmas 

Bill Bryson assembles a few hours of impeccably researched information and personal anecdotes about Christmas. 

As always, the writing is pitch perfect and laugh out loud funny. 

It‚Äôs only available as an audiobook read by Bryson, which is a minor demerit in itself but also because Bryson is a middling reader. 

I don‚Äôt especially like Christmas but I could read Bill Bryson on any subject. Actuarial science? Sign me up. The use of slide rules in the age of calculators? I‚Äôm there. But for those of you who get way into Christmas, don‚Äôt miss this. 

It especially shines when it‚Äôs looking at the different traditions of nations. 

Four stars by Bryson standards.

Skunk Works 

The story of Lockheed‚Äôs justifiably fetishized engineering A team as told by the man who ran it. 

Let me start by saying that this book is fun. Spellbinding even.

But it‚Äôs also a piece of critical education on how to get shit done inside a behemoth bureaucracy. In short: split off a group of the top performers, give them important tasks, and install a leader at the top who insulates them from the rest of the organization‚Äôs bullshit. 

Lockheed churned out a parade of the greatest hits of military aviation with this approach (p38, U2, sr71, etc). And the whole startup scene applies roughly the same model to solving tech problems. A good startup is, itself, like a Skunk Works. 

It has just enough aeronautical engineering to give it an exotic flavor without bogging it down. Ben Rich tells just the right number of stories about the planes‚Äô exploits in the world to make you feel how high the stakes were. 

It‚Äôs even better than you‚Äôd imagine. Five stars for its class.

book_title: Kelly: More Than My Share of It All
text:
Kelly: More Than My Share of It All

Kelly Johnson tells his story, focusing on his time running Lockheed‚Äôs vaunted Skunk Works.

This is a full autobiography, not just a memoir of his Skunk Works days, but it‚Äôs all captivating. The meat of it covers the birth of Skunk Works up until the handoff to Ben Rich.

If you‚Äôre planning on reading both (you should!), read this one first. If you‚Äôre only going to read one, read Ben Rich‚Äôs Skunk Works.

One of the strongest markers of Skunk Works‚Äô magic is that it worked at peak level under two different leaders. Had it thrived only under one or the other, I‚Äôd chalk it up as attributable to the influence of a charismatic leader. But surviving the transition of power reveals an influential team culture independent of leadership. So read both books. 

This book is heavier on human interest stuff than Ben Rich‚Äôs, and if you‚Äôre a sucker for stories about Depression kids making big impacts, you‚Äôll love it, even if you‚Äôre not into aviation.

Five stars

Hillbilly Elegy

A kid grows up in a poor, dysfunctional family and somehow makes it into Yale. 

My wife, a devoted memoir reader, read this when it came out and hated it. The only books we‚Äôve ever mutually loved have Harry Potter in the title, so this was a positive signal for me. 

Turned out there wasn‚Äôt much to love nor much to hate in my experience. The writing was respectable but not remarkable. The story was familiar for those of us who grew up in socioeconomically analogous communities. Same with its insights‚Äînothing too surprising. That is, unless you‚Äôre a coastal elite in a bubble, and then it apparently blows your mind. 

For a directly comparable masterpiece of the genre, read The Glass Castle. For a similar story with different textures, read Angela‚Äôs Ashes or This Boy‚Äôs Life. 

Three stars for its class, mostly unexceptional.

Tribe

Sebastian Junger posits that the cure for modern ennui is fierce loyalty and intense belonging in a small, tight knit group.

The thesis of the book starts with the assumption that people are miserable despite society‚Äôs fabulous wealth. He‚Äôs such a good writer that I have to actively remind myself to query whether that‚Äôs even true.

But hey, buy the ticket, take the ride. Assuming it is true, he asserts that the reason for the misery is a lack of belonging and purpose. He cites as evidence the fact that people sometimes miss wars and fondly remember crises, because situations like those force us into tribes. You need to be willing to die for someone else for life to have meaning, he asserts.

Regardless of whether the whole line of reasoning holds up, his prescription is a good one: double down on loyalty and dedication to your people to make yourself happier. 

Go call your mom, partner, kids, whatever. Tell them Sebastian Junger sent you.

Three stars by SJ standards. High bar; worth reading!

In My Time of Dying

Sebastian Junger comes within spitting distance of death, and writes a book about it. 

It‚Äôs especially fun to read it in the context of his other books. All the uncertainty about meaning and purpose that came through in Tribe and Freedom evaporates in the face of death. 

He spends more time talking about his family in this book than in the rest combined, which I suspect is not a coincidence. He‚Äôs always had a knack for making readers sympathetically feel things deeply, and clearly the near death experience shook him to his core. 

He gets a bit squirrelly about theories of supernatural experience, but as always, his storytelling, writing, and research are amazing. Even the opening anecdote about cold water surfing sticks in my mind. 

If you like SJ or books about death, this is essential reading. If not, I recommend it nonetheless. 

Four stars by SJ standards.

The Wright Brothers

David McCullough documents the Wright brothers‚Äô engineering triumph. 

The book does justice to its story, and the story is every bit as good as one would hope, given the technical and cultural impact of flight. 

I especially liked the parts about their time in Kitty Hawk, which was more or less wilderness at that point. 

McCullough also does a great job dispelling the myth that the Wright brothers were simple mechanics who tinkered their way to success. They were serious businessmen, serious engineers, and serious scientists. They also possessed a species of focus and drive that we now associate with successful founders. 

I never realized how slow the world was to accept the reality of the Wright Flyer. It was such a different world back then. 

Strongly recommended. This and Bill Bryson‚Äôs 1927 book would make a great one-two punch. 

Five stars for its class.

The River of Doubt

Millard tells the story of TR‚Äôs ill fated trip into the Amazon.

The story itself is great. The book is full of interesting characters. But the storytelling does justice to neither, and the book falls flat.

It‚Äôs at its best just reciting a litany of jungle horrors.

Two stars for its class.

Angela‚Äôs Ashes

Frank McCourt tells the story of growing up in a poor, dysfunctional family in Brooklyn and Limerick. 

The author‚Äôs grace, humor, and empathy elevate this book above the standard crop of poverty porn memoirs, even those that share its S tier writing and storytelling. 

It‚Äôs mystifying to me how someone could so effectively convey that much pathos, despite having clearly matured and recovered so completely. 

But somehow he manages to, and the result for the reader is that you feel McCourt‚Äôs pain deeply, but without the emotional hangover that often accompanies this type of book. 

I think part of it is that the Irish as a culture are especially well equipped to process sadness and misery. But there‚Äôs something singular about McCourt, even in that cultural context. 

Your heart breaks as you see Frank coming to understand his dad‚Äôs ‚Äúodd manner,‚Äù but you don‚Äôt feel like offing yourself after. 

The audiobook is read by McCourt, strongly recommended.

Five stars, a masterpiece.

The Inimitable Jeeves

PG Wodehouse stitches a bunch of inane short stories into an insufferable novel. 

Quoting from my contemporaneous review:

‚ÄúJust the worst. If you‚Äôre the type of person who laughs by turning down the corners of your mouth, lifting your chin, and pushing small chuckles from deep in your throat out of your nose, you might find something to like here. No likable or interesting characters, no development, no unifying story. Just more or less detached episodes of obnoxious people getting into silly, boring situations. The writing is nowhere near as good as its reputation suggests.‚Äù

I stand by that. I will add as additional flavor that this was the end of my run of mining Paul Graham‚Äôs book recommendations. 

Not good, not funny, not worth reading.

Ireland 

Frank Delaney tells the history of Ireland through a series of fictional stories. 

This is like a kids‚Äô illustrated book, except instead of actual drawings it has interwoven fictional stories to hold adults‚Äô interest across 650 pages of genuine history. 

The frame tale is compelling enough to keep everything feeling unified, all the way from the ice age to Ireland‚Äôs bloody twentieth century. 

The stories inside the frame are packed with Irish history, myth, character. 

It‚Äôs an agreeable way to learn a whole bunch of Irish history. The audiobook does justice to the Irish oral storytelling tradition. 

I‚Äôve never read a book quite like this, so right now it‚Äôs alone in its class. Read it if you‚Äôre visiting Ireland or going through one of those phases where you‚Äôre excited about your Irish heritage.

Nausea

Sartre tells a sad and miserable story about a sad and miserable man. 

This book, in its way, is one of the most puritanical and life-denying books I‚Äôve ever read. It‚Äôs like something written by a moody, depressive, precocious teenager. 

The protagonist is bored and boring, and instead of doing something, he doubles down on his misery, wallowing around in solipsistic thought loops that make him even more miserable. 

And the entire time, there‚Äôs this self satisfied smirking undertone as if the protagonist, the author, and any sufficiently sensitive reader will know that this is really the best‚Äîthe only!‚Äîway to live. 

Existence is not hard to cope with and meaning is not hard to manufacture, even if it doesn‚Äôt smack you in the face when you walk out the door. 

A sad, stupid, boring book that is overdue to be forgotten. 

One star, skip it.

The Core of an Onion

Mark Kurlansky looks at the cultural and culinary history of the onion. 

If you haven‚Äôt read Kurlansky before, it‚Äôs hard to believe that a book about a commodity could be so interesting. 

It‚Äôs surprisingly dynamic. He moves quickly from one well researched topic to another, but you never get the feeling that he‚Äôs wedging something in just to fill space or just because he went to the trouble of researching it. It‚Äôs everything you would want to know about onions and no more. 

I love alliums, especially onions, and I got a kick out of the recipes. I‚Äôve made and enjoyed some, but I haven‚Äôt worked up the courage to try Hemingway‚Äôs peanut butter and onion sandwich. 

Agreeable nonfiction, four stars by  Kurlansky standards. If you‚Äôre new to him, read Salt and Cod first. But if you like those, read this.

The Name of the Rose

Umberto Eco puts Holmes and Watson into Monks‚Äô robes and sets them up against a whodunit in a Medieval monastery. 

I got sick of mining ‚Äúbest books of <some criterion>‚Äù lists, because they all have some agenda to push. So I decided to look at the list of best selling books of all time and this stood out to me. The market can‚Äôt be that wrong, can it?

NO, IT CANNOT. THE MARKET IS NEVER WRONG. 

At least it wasn‚Äôt in this case. This was a delight. The plot is fun, the characters are human and balanced,  and the setting is a hoot. I don‚Äôt normally read mysteries, so this felt especially exotic to me. 

If you liked The DaVinci Code, you will probably like this. But even if you disliked The DaVinci Code, you might like this, because it‚Äôs a much better book.

Venice 

Thomas F Madden deftly conveys the peculiar history of Venice. 

Turns out it‚Äôs a lot more Byzantine than I expected, in all senses of that word. 

It was effectively independent for much of its history, and its affiliations with the descendants of the Western Roman Empire and the descendants Eastern Roman Empire shifted often. It served as an interface for the two, and at times rose to the level of a peer. 

I also discovered, reading this book, that they beat the west to the punch on an early version of republican government. 

Exhaustively researched, well told, and brimming with novel information. 

Four stars in a highly competitive class, strongly recommended.

The Medici

Paul Strathern tells the story of the rise and fall of renaissance Italy‚Äôs greatest banking dynasty. 

I‚Äôd enjoyed Venice so much that I decided to pick another history book from @july‚Äôs list. It was even better. 

There‚Äôs enough human drama and intrigue to rival Game of Thrones. The cast of characters is populated with demigods like Michelangelo, DaVinci, Galileo, and Machiavelli. 

And all throughout, you get a behind the scenes look at the Medicis pulling the strings. They were partly a product of the renaissance, but they were a core driver of its genesis as well. 

You come to admire or at least respect the Medici so much over the first two acts that the decadence and decline in the third act is genuinely poignant. You feel a rewarding kind of self righteous disgust to see such a legacy squandered.

It‚Äôs a great story. It‚Äôs also a handbook on the things to do and not to do if you earnestly want to touch the lives of descendants you will never live to meet. 

Five stars, must read.

book_title: Sir Gawain and the Green Knight
text:
Sir Gawain and the Green Knight

Arthurian knight Gawain decapitates the green knight. The green knight collects his head and departs with a challenge to Gawain that sets him on a quest. 

My boys and I listened to the Simon Armitage translation on Simon Sarris‚Äôs recommendation. It does a great job conveying the lilting alliterative verse of the opaque original Middle English version. 

The language is hypnotic to the extent that the story doesn‚Äôt have to carry much weight for young listeners. If you‚Äôve ever read Chicka Chicka Boom Boom to a 1yo, you know what I mean. 

But the story holds up, though it feels bizarre and very foreign. 

If you‚Äôre ever in the mood for something short and way out of the ordinary, this will fit the bill. 

Feeling fair, I favor it with four stars for fanciful flowing fiction.

Beowulf

The eponymous character bails Hrothgar out of his trouble with Grendel. Grendel‚Äôs mom comes back at him swinging hard, but all Beowulf does is win, so they make him king. Much later, old man Beowulf dies fighting a dragon, though team Beowulf eventually secures the W. 

It‚Äôs a bedrock story, the mythical foundation on which a lot of our modern fantasy rests. It‚Äôs also surprisingly palatable for modern audiences. Lindy for good reason. 

The story is compelling enough that you don‚Äôt need to burn too many calories finding the ideal translation. It‚Äôs also pretty short, so it‚Äôs not like you‚Äôre making a huge commitment. 

It reminded me of the Rohan scenes in LOTR. If you like fantasy or mythology, you should read it.

book_title: All Quiet on the Western Front
text:
All Quiet on the Western Front

Remarque shows in livid detail how bad war is for a soldier.

Synopsis:

I‚Äôm excited for war, but wait, actually it‚Äôs bad. Bad bad bad bad bad. Miserable. Bad bad bad. Grotesque. Bad. Crippling. Bad. Bad. Bad. We eat a stolen goose! Bad. All my friends are dead.

It‚Äôs an unflinching rendition of what has since become a familiar pattern: wide eyed boy ships out eager and then discovers through extensive firsthand misery that death and pain flavor his war experience much more than glory and adventure.

But it‚Äôs mostly a one note symphony. It ignores that some moments might be exciting or meaningful (see War by Sebastian Junger) and it doesn‚Äôt plumb the emotional depths of its protagonist in interesting ways like Red Badge of Courage does. It runs its protagonist through a gauntlet of traumatic experiences and leaves the reader to imagine the resulting feelings.

More realistic than its ancestors? Yes. But not all it‚Äôs cracked up to be and since outpaced.

Three stars.

King Solomon‚Äôs Mines

Haggard‚Äôs story about an African El Dorado invents the lost world genre.

If this is the only book in the cottage and the storm raging outside prevents the boat from carrying you back to the mainland from the Outer Hebrides, then read it by candlelight.

Otherwise, skip it.

Plutarch‚Äôs Lives

I only read four of the fortyish biographies, but I counted it on my list because they‚Äôre all isolated and the four amounted to book length. 

The two historical figures, Cicero and Marc Antony, were presented in a different light than I‚Äôd seen them in before. The two mythological figures received more familiar treatment, but in greater detail. 

I‚Äôll definitely return to this. It‚Äôs great for those of us who think about the Roman Empire every day.

Tarzan of the Apes

Capable boy raised by apes grows into a man, rescues some marooned travelers. 

Some cultural avenues have been so long extended and so well trodden by Hollywood that returning to their origins produces a feeling of novelty that exceeds what one experiences in genuinely exotic territory. 

The earnestness and na√Øvet√© of this book, as it discovers lately exhausted characters, themes, and plots has a charm of its own. But it‚Äôs also a fun, if anachronistically innocent, adventure story in itself. 

Tarzan is a lovable character. The book version of the character is smart, in addition to being a capable vine swinger. You root for him with Jane like you‚Äôd root for a hapless nephew going to his first school dance.

This was good enough that, after reading it on my own, I put it into the queue of books to read with my kids.

Two Years before the Mast

Harvard kid ships out with a merchant and learns the ropes. He goes to San Francisco, then a settlement of a few adobe structures, to trade.

I am grateful to @links for putting this gem on my radar. It‚Äôs exactly on point for me:

- erudite narrator
- sea adventure 
- accounts of places I know in times I don‚Äôt 

The book assumes that its reader is intelligent and patient, and gives a corresponding level of detail, but never enough to exhaust the reader. 

This book clearly inspired Moby Dick, Captains Courageous, the Aubrey Maturin series, and others. You can smell the brine on it. 

But it‚Äôs not all nautical. The middle section introduces the reader to the California coast back when SF, LA, and SD all had populations well below 1000. Their main export in those days was cowhide, and we learn the travails of buying, processing, and transporting them. 

It‚Äôs also packed with great characters and fun tangential anecdotes. 

Five stars, banger.

book_title: Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde
text:
Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde

Respectable Dr Jekyll loses the battle against his dark alter ego Mr Hyde. 

If you‚Äôre into gothic horror, which is to say horror where nothing actually scary or horrifying happens, then you should read this. It‚Äôll only take you a couple hours. 

Otherwise, you can probably just remain content with your familiarity with the Jekyll/Hyde dichotomy. 

Do not, like me, make the mistake of reading this book with the expectation of finding something more nuanced or interesting than that. There‚Äôs no fun adventure and the twist, such as it is, has no extra punch in the context of the full work. 

Eminently skippable.

The Long Goodbye 

Private detective stubbornly tries to untangle the sordid affairs of an interconnected set of affluent LA-centric degenerates. 

Long indeed. And I was relieved to say goodbye. I never got deeply invested in anyone, even Marlowe. And the convoluted plot didn‚Äôt do it for me. 

Even the infinitely cool vibe of this kind of character and setting, that we know and love from the film noir expressions of the genre, didn‚Äôt come through for me. 

Instead, it just felt cold, flat, distant and dull, with an occasional whiplash inducing twist. 

Marlowe‚Äôs conscience and emotional core were even harder to build mental models for than they are in a movie like The Big Sleep. I just can‚Äôt reach the hows and whys. I can‚Äôt harmonize the rough surface with the heart of gold. 

At the end of the day, I think this kind of story just wants to be a movie more than it wants to be a novel.

Not recommended. But take it with a grain of salt, because I rarely enjoy detective novels.

This Boy‚Äôs Life

Wolff recalls growing up badly behaved in bad circumstances. 

Even if you don‚Äôt like the merciless self deprecatory character development, you will find yourself engrossed in the stories. They are, for the most part, good stories. And they are uniformly well told. 

Reading this book feels a lot more like reading a Bildungsroman than a memoir. He‚Äôs almost too writerly for the genre. Think: when you see a shot in a documentary that‚Äôs so well composed that it breaks the illusion of immediacy and makes you remember you‚Äôre watching a movie. 

As long as you‚Äôre the type of reader who can abide an unloveable protagonist, you should read this book. It‚Äôs not worth dropping everything to chase down a copy, but if you liked Angela‚Äôs Ashes and The Glass Castle, you will like this (though not as much as those).

Kiki‚Äôs Delivery Service 

Young witch sets out on her own. 

You know how sometimes you Ghiblify a mediocre picture and it turns out amazing? That‚Äôs what we‚Äôve got here. 

It‚Äôs a top 3 Miyazaki movie for me, so when my 6yo picked it I was psyched. And we‚Äôd read and loved Howl‚Äôs Moving Castle. 

But it turns out that the vast majority of the magic of the movie was added by Ghibli. The book was flat, dull, and childishly simple in comparison. 

I didn‚Äôt enjoy it. My 6yo did, but not as much as Coraline or The Ocean at the End of the Lane.

Strange Glow

A measured, balanced, data driven look at the history, costs, and benefits of radiation. 

I asked my dentist for a book recommendation and he suggested this. It turned out to be a great read. 

A lot of it is science history, which I always love. 

The last third or so weighs the benefits and risks of therapeutic and diagnostic radiation. 

If your broken ulna is sticking out of the skin, don‚Äôt bother with the X ray. If it‚Äôs barely bruised, same. But the clarity you get from the X ray pays for itself if it allows the doctor to determine whether you need a cast. That kind of thing. Turns out mammograms might have only marginal benefit, if any, all things considered. 

Good for anyone interested in the history and health impacts of radiation. 

And of course, the radium girls make an appearance. 

Strongly recommended!

Life

Keith Richards tells his story with humor and aplomb.

Anyone who‚Äôs been successful in the arts for so long or negotiated a fragile contract with substances for so long is going to have an interesting story. 

As you‚Äôd expect, Keith Richards has an interesting story. 

What you might not expect is how well told it is. He‚Äôs smarter, more sensitive, and wiser than I would have guessed. And his ghost writer let Keith‚Äôs voice shine through in an authentic way, so the whole thing sounds right. 

You get stories of boyhood, of the rise to fame, of substance abuse, of and of intra-band drama. And a whole lot of deep love for music. 

It‚Äôs pretty much pitch perfect. Even if you don‚Äôt like the man‚Äôs music, it‚Äôs just a great book. 

And incredibly, for all that hard living, you get a happy ending. Aside from the occasional fall out of a palm tree or off a bookshelf, he has a nice, fairly mellow life now. He reads a lot, and shouts out the Aubrey-Maturin series, one of my favorites. 

Can‚Äôt miss.

Captains Courageous 

Ultra rich kid rescued from North Atlantic by cod fishermen, forced to work for months, receives enough routine psychological wear and tear to grow into a man. 

It‚Äôs all so optimistic, sincere, well intentioned that I found it easy to forgive the trite parts. Good medicine for kids and tweens. Nearly but not entirely entertaining enough to hold their interest. 

Read it to your kids if you can, but only if they already love books. Otherwise read whatever they love until you‚Äôve clinched the habit. My boys were neutral to it. 

Not the kind of thing any adult should read independently.

Bulfinch‚Äôs Mythology

Eminently digestible and sanitized rendition of classical myths. 

Even with some of the juice robbed out of them, these are timeless and entertaining tales. 

I strongly encourage you to read mythology, especially Greek and Roman. Read every version you get your hands on until you can‚Äôt keep them all straight and you can‚Äôt help but create your own version when you tell it aloud to your friends and family. 

There‚Äôs nothing as Lindy. Try allocating even 5-10% of your reading time to myths for a while and see if they don‚Äôt claim proportionally more mental real estate. 

Start with a direct translation of the Homeric Hymns or Metamorphoses and branch out from there.

The Aeneid

Aeneas travels from fallen Troy to Italy, fights a war, and founds Rome. 

The underlying story is exactly on point for me, but the Robert Fagles translation didn‚Äôt quite hit the spot. 

Anyone have a favorite translation? I‚Äôd like to give it another shot.

Showdown on the Hogback

A smart, tough gunslinger gets hired to drive some lowlife squatters off a patch of desert, but when he discovers they‚Äôre really hardworking families, he flips sides to help defend them. 

The space in the public consciousness for guilty pleasure novels for men seems to shrink even more rapidly than it does for women.  Louis L‚Äôamour is a good deal better than many of the other writers who served the niche during its heyday, but it‚Äôs hard to imagine that his work will survive many more generations. 

It‚Äôs the kind of book that a guy might have stuffed in his pocket to read on the subway or kept on the bedside table to wind down with at night. In other words, it filled the role that doomscrolling on social media does now. 

And in the competition for attention, it‚Äôs no fight at all. Like a colt revolver against a tomahawk missle. But a lot of our experience is downstream of our information intake, and you should consider flipping sides and fighting for the good guys sometimes.

Endurance 

True story of Shackleton leading his men to safety after losing their ship in Antarctic latitudes. 

It‚Äôs one of the all time great true survival stories. The crew spent over a year stranded on ice floes and desolate islands, hunted seals and penguins for food, and crossed the infamous Drake Passage in an open boat. 

Across all that, no lives were lost, only a couple frostbite amputations were necessary, and if Lansing is to be believed, morale never even got too bad. 

The detail of the physical trials and privations makes the environment come alive, and the steady stream of stories of minor interpersonal conflicts provide a convincing social context. 

Great research, very good writing, and a remarkable story. I can‚Äôt wait until I can ask ChatGPT to make a feature film of this in the style of Master and Commander üòÜ

Thanks to @links for reminding me about it. 

Highly recommended for kids and adults.

Middlemarch

High resolution realistic portrayal of provincial England in the early 19th century.

Middlemarch is to Jane Austen‚Äôs work as The Breakfast Club is to Clueless. In other words, it‚Äôs a good deal more substantial, nuanced, and empathetic. Plus, it tackles a broader and more serious range of subjects.

The times, places, language, manners, and values are all clearly drawn from the same pool. But beneath the superficially similar textures, the bones are radically different.

Over the course of the novel, you get to know the strengths and flaws of a whole bunch of characters, and you come to feel deeply for even those with more flaws than strengths.

I love novels like this because they remind me that even among the insignificant people of podunk places, everyone‚Äôs experiencing life with an intensity that merits a massive epic novel.

It‚Äôs a lot of work to read, but it pays for itself along the way. Excellent book but daunting. Read it for sure if you like Jane Austen and are also smart

D-Day

Stephen Ambrose covers the D Day topic in detail and more broadly. 

It‚Äôs more or less a superset of the information and stories from The Longest Day. I‚Äôd give a slight edge to Ryan‚Äôs work for storytelling and writing. Ryan‚Äôs prose is punchier and more journalistic. Ambrose‚Äôs will only seem a little flat in direct comparison, though. It‚Äôs still very good. 

Both are incredible overall, and you can choose freely between the two based entirely on how many pages you want to read on the topic. 

I enjoyed them both so much that I‚Äôm currently reading Band of Brothers now. 

Well told war stories are as good as it gets. This is why our stick wielding ancestors learned language. 

Highest recommendation.

Band of Brothers 

The book that inspired the series that follows a special military unit from D Day to VE Day.

If you‚Äôve seen the series (you should!), you know almost exactly what to expect here. The show does a remarkably faithful job of translating the book to the screen. 

A lot of the key dialogue lines are quotes from the soldiers, and a lot of the most memorable narration is pulled verbatim from Ambrose. 

If you haven‚Äôt experienced either, the series is so good that you can take your pick between reading the book or watching the show. If you already love the show, the book will be enjoyable but it won‚Äôt blow your mind. Better to go with the D Day book instead, which has the same feel but covers different ground. 

‚Äú‚ÄòGrandpa, were you a hero in the war?‚Äô Grandpa said, ‚ÄòNo. But I served in a company of heroes.‚Äô‚Äù

It brings me to the verge of tears every time. 

Highest recommendation. The definitive war story of the quintessential modern war. Magical from first to last.

book_title: The Unreasonable Virtue of Fly Fishing
text:
The Unreasonable Virtue of Fly Fishing

Mark Kurlansky does his signature exposition on fly fishing. 

It‚Äôs mediocre compared to his other work. He‚Äôs not a serious fisherman, which grates on me. And his heart clearly wasn‚Äôt in this one. 

There‚Äôs probably a Goldilocks zone where you could care enough about fly fishing to be interested but not so much that this seems shallow and inartful. 

But to be safe, I‚Äôm not recommending this to anyone. 

I love Kurlansky and I love fly fishing. Such a bummer that this was not good. 

My parents got me it for Christmas and have followed up about it multiple times or I would not have even finished it. In case they ever find this:

Hi mom! üëã

The Bible

Foundational text of Christianity. 

A lot of my favorite writers were quite fond of this book either for its substance or its poetry, or both. So I went into it not just with an open mind, but actively seeking the magic that so many serious people have found in it for so many centuries. 

I did not find much of anything remarkable. What I discovered instead is that Christianity as it‚Äôs commonly known is substantially extra-textual and the Judeo-Christian literary heritage is a product of layering by subsequent authors.

The Bible itself, as a literary work, does not offer much. It has its moments. The Song of Solomon stood out to me, for example. But if you throw that much at the wall something is bound to stick. It seemed to me that most of the Old Testament consisted of measurements in cubits for the construction of various sacred objects. 

The New Testament at least emphasizes love and mercy, but in a simplistic way. No really touching moments.

Not inspiring, not beautiful, not recommended.

21 Cup

Precise exposition of the rules for a variant of beer pong.

Some games have virtually no stakes and are played for the mere joy of playing. Some games are high stakes and require very precise definitions of acceptable play.

Beer pong falls squarely into the former category, but when it becomes a cherished ritual among a set of bright, intense young people overflowing with energy, you end up with a book like 21 Cup. With cheer and humor, it gives a self consciously thorough and serious enumeration of the rules of the game.

One of my favorite parts of reading is modeling the mental state of the author at the time of writing. Between its dry, legalistic lines, 21 Cup tells a tacit story of a tribe of young men, flush with the power, joy, and optimism of their early twenties, bonding over the love of a simple game, which really just serves as a vessel for their mutual respect, fondness, and admiration.

Recommended for anyone whose life includes a warmly remembered beer pong chapter.

Women

Bukowski kisses and tells.

I read this as a palette cleanser between the Bible and the Quran. I remember loving Bukowski‚Äô prose, perspective, and subject matter in my early twenties. 

But this was a serious letdown. The writing was raw and direct, but not as potent as I recalled. The whole thing just came off as misogynistic and mildly pornographic. The only grasps at a higher literary tier were the occasional references to poetry readings, the broader misanthropy, and the revealed self loathing. 

I want to make it clear that I am not a prude. I understand desire. I feel desire strongly. I like writing that authentically conveys desire. But Bukowski‚Äôs thoughts and behaviors as recorded here seem more like deliberately hostile consumption than the aching, yearning, worshipping experience of desire that makes sense and feels right to me.

I recommended avoiding this. If you want to read a filthy old man‚Äôs writings about sex, read Memories of my Melancholy Whores instead.

The Caine Mutiny

Civilian becomes a captain of a minesweeper over the course of WWII. 

‚ÄúThe Navy is a master plan designed by geniuses for execution by idiots.‚Äù

The pain of coming to grips with this reality lies at the core of this book. The passably smart, reasonably independently thinking protagonist struggles with the dilemma, sometimes discarding his own rational reactions to formalistic bureaucratic nonsense and sometimes recoiling so strongly that he can‚Äôt help but reject the system level demands imposed by the distant geniuses. 

The court martial concerning the mutiny mentioned in the title is usually referred to as the dramatic climax, but the post mortem delivered by the conflicted defense attorney afterwards was, for me, by far the best scene. 

Other than one slow section near the middle, the whole book is outstanding. It feels grown up and sophisticated without being daunting or fatiguing.

Highly recommended. Lots of fun and full of insights applicable to any bureaucracy.

Darkness at Noon

Former Soviet Party superstar languishes in prison while awaiting execution by the Soviets. 

Not recommended. 

These people are just the worst. The book is largely an assertion along the lines of ‚Äúus old Bolsheviks were making good progress toward trying real communism and then these Stalinist thugs came and ruined it.‚Äù

Which is, of course, stupid on its face. 

Soviet thinking had all the worst vices of religious thinking and none of its virtues. It‚Äôs so exhausting to listen to the performative rhetoric competition. ‚ÄúHow far can I distort my worldview? Did you distort your worldview enough to escape the KGB death squads?‚Äù

There‚Äôs pretty much nothing else to this book. 

Warning: I‚Äôm going to block anyone who shows up in the replies defending any flavor of Marxism, Bolshevism, Stalinism, etc.

The Courage to Be Disliked

Dialogue lays out the fundamentals of Adlerian psychology as the most effective self help strategy.

The title is so good, the book has tons of sales, the reviews were glowing, and the connection to Japanese culture was so tantalizing. But the book turned out to be just one of the many dime-a-dozen self help books that grab onto some specific mode of psychology and tell you to stop worrying because now you have their special insight. 

If you‚Äôre a troubled teenager, go for it. Or for any of its near clones. Otherwise, skip it.

The Cruel Sea

Novel about a group of UK men serving on an escort ship in the Atlantic during WWII. 

Outstanding book. It‚Äôs split about 60/40 between sea related narrative and the lives of the men as men. 

The horrors of war are presented unflinchingly, but faced with that famous Anglo Saxon stiff upper lip. The pride of service, the sense of duty, and the onboard camaraderie counterbalance the misery of fighting the elements and the enemy. 

The stories of the men‚Äôs lives on shore were particularly good and surprisingly honest given the book‚Äôs age. One character falls in love, fathers a child out of wedlock, receives a letter while abroad that the mother intends to abort it, and replies that she should keep it. A few days later he learns that she‚Äôd been killed before he even got her letter. Touching stuff and written with deep empathy. 

I‚Äôm surprised this book isn‚Äôt talked about more. Recommended generally. Strongly recommended for fans of war stories.

But fabulous 

https://www.cabinetmagazine.org/issues/25/duprat.php

Fire

Sebastian Junger covers a set of disparate topics, unified by their danger. 

It‚Äôs not a coherent, focused look at one thing, which is a minor demerit. But it beats the alternative of tracking down a bunch of National Geographic magazines just to read his work. 

The stories about Kosovo, escaping captivity, forest fire fighters, and traditional whaling in the Caribbean stuck with me in particular. 

It‚Äôs all ~25 years past the point of journalistic relevance, but the writing and storytelling is as good as ever. 

Recommended for fans of Junger, but if you‚Äôre not yet a fan, read his other stuff first, starting with The Perfect Storm and War.

Kim

Orphan boy comes of age, studies under a spiritual mentor, and becomes a spy, all simultaneously. 

It works as adventure story and as a snapshot of India around the start of the 20th century. It kind of works as a coming of age story. Its spiritual facet doesn‚Äôt shine like the others. 

I went in with high expectations based on descriptions and reviews, but it didn‚Äôt deliver quite like I hoped. Some parts felt cheesy and shallow. And the espionage intrigue never developed as fully as I was hoping. 

But it‚Äôs undeniably fun just to take a tour through India in the late 1800s. 

I wouldn‚Äôt warn someone off if they wanted to read it. But I can‚Äôt think of an audience I‚Äôd actively recommend it to.

Notes from Underground

Bitter, spiteful, unreliable narrator absolutely drags rationality, determinism, and himself. 

This is not a fun book. I did not enjoy reading it. The first half isn‚Äôt even a story, just a screed. The second half is a brutal portrait of the narrator as the worst kind of person.

I‚Äôd be prepared to forgive all that if not for the fact that it didn‚Äôt even surface any especially novel or plausible ideas. 

If you liked Crime and Punishment, this might appeal to you. But if you, like me, find yourself looking for Dostoevsky titles because you loved The Brothers Karamazov, look elsewhere.

Ethan Frome

Ethan falls in love with Mattie, the cousin of his miserable wife, to disastrous results. 

It‚Äôs a lovely, tender, tight little book. It‚Äôs faithful and fair to both the strict social norms of its setting and the feelings that provide the impetus for their transgression. 

While Ethan‚Äôs wife Zeena is a bit less complex than Ethan and Mattie, her unflattering portrait is perhaps the most memorable of all. But across the board the character development is terrific. 

You also get an uncommonly strong sense of place from the book. If you‚Äôve ever experienced the northeastern United States in the winter, it‚Äôll make you reach for your warmest coat. 

It‚Äôs the opposite of flashy. It lacks the garish gestures that characterize modern romance stories, and it ends in tragedy. But despite all that, in its understated way, it‚Äôs one of the most romantic books I‚Äôve ever read. Despite all the physical and emotional frigidity, it‚Äôs kinda hot. 

Highly recommended.

My Antonia

Loving portrait of a young immigrant girl growing into adulthood on the frontier.

The narrator is an orphan who moves to the frontier around the same time as Antonia, and falls in love with her. You will, too. She‚Äôs tough, charming, and overflowing with life. 

The book is also a portrait of Antonia‚Äôs time, place, and people. It works well on all those fronts as well. Wonderful anecdotes, wonderful characters.

The prose leaned more poetic than was good for it at times, but that‚Äôs my only quibble. 

Reading this felt like being initiated into something secret and beautiful. I love this kind of love. 

Recommended for anyone.

Lord Jim

Young Jim, who is not really a lord of any sort, grapples with his past. 

You can flip this book open to any page, read a few paragraphs, and know you‚Äôre reading good writing. But if you don‚Äôt keep your head in the game, the entire book will feel like that. 

The narrative structure is not ergonomic, and the majority of book kind of obliquely looks at its actual subject. So it‚Äôs not an easy read. 

But Conrad is a master at conjuring a mood, and if you put in the work that this book asks of you, you‚Äôll find a meaningful coherence beneath its seemingly disjointed narrative. Worst case, it‚Äôs a bunch of compelling short stories. 

Don‚Äôt run to the library this moment, but if you get a chance to read it, don‚Äôt turn it down. Cautiously recommended.

A River Runs Through It

A family of fly fishermen lose a brother. 

This is the best fishing book. And it‚Äôs also a beautifully written piece of literature, even for those who don‚Äôt fish. 

I‚Äôve read maybe a dozen fishing books, and with the exception of John Gierach‚Äôs books, I‚Äôve found them all at least a little off putting as a consequence of the authors‚Äô varying degrees of poseur. Most were filthy casuals, even those who purported to be dedicated or addicted.

Norman Maclean is the real thing. He‚Äôs a true fisherman. It matters to me, but only because of that Gell-Mann amnesia effect. 

What will matter to many more is that he‚Äôs also an outstanding writer and storyteller. He writes with humor and poetry, but always stays grounded. 

I held off reading this because I love the movie and I didn‚Äôt want a sub par book to compromise my enjoyment. Far from it, turned out. 

Recommended for everyone. Highly recommended for anyone who fishes or loves someone who fishes.

Born Standing Up

Comedy legend briefly tells his story from birth to the top.

It‚Äôs a treat. He‚Äôs smart, sincere, and sensitive throughout, which took me slightly by surprise since he so often plays the opposite type of character.

But it‚Äôs never heavy handed, and it offers its fair share of laughs, too.

Another great example of someone grinding for decades to earn overnight success. 

Recommended for all. Would make a great plane, train, or beach book.

Our Man in Havana

British expat recruited as a spy in pre-revolution Cuba, takes the gig for the money, dark hijinks ensue. 

The 2025 film adaptation would be directed by the Coen Brothers. The whole vibe feels a lot like a tropical version of Burn After Reading. 

It was fun and entertaining, with a bit more meat on its bones than a pure bubblegum spy thriller. Also more self aware and humorous. 

Casually recommended if you‚Äôre looking for something in its niche.

Me Talk Pretty One Day

Hilarious writer does a couple dozen bits. 

There are no great ideas to be mined. There‚Äôs no coherent thesis. It‚Äôs not a Great Book. 

But it is a great book, and it made me laugh out loud a bunch of times. Lots of fun. 

Recommended.

Hitchhiker‚Äôs Guide to the Galaxy

Arthur Dent narrowly survives the end of the world, then things get tough. 

If you like sci fi but haven‚Äôt read this, you absolutely must. There‚Äôs a chance you won‚Äôt like it, but it‚Äôs more likely that you‚Äôll love it. 

The plot is pretty manic and disjointed, and there‚Äôs not a lot of character development in the traditional sense, thought there are a lot of memorable personalities. 

It‚Äôs really just a vehicle for a whole bunch of hilarious lines. And it roasts sci-fi with obvious love. 

I laughed out loud when I read it the first time. My 6yo and I laughed out loud on this pass.

Strongly recommended for fans of sci-fi and humor. And for anglophiles, too, now that I think of it.

Delta-v

Near future tale of commercial deep space asteroid mining.

It takes its time getting up to speed, but once it hits its stride, it‚Äôs a lot of fun. 

This book hit my radar in the course of a conversation with July about the practical realities of space commerce. Like that exposition, this book is gratifyingly grounded in both physics and economics. Reading this book or talking with July, you get the feeling that this kind of thing is achievable and all that‚Äôs missing is imagination, will, and a few billion dollars in funding. 

My main gripe with the book is that entirely too much time was allocated to Rochat the space lawyer. His chapters felt bland compared to those of Tighe the protagonist. Suarez could use a better, more persuasive editor. 

But it‚Äôs worth it to go with Tighe and his smart, tough, high agency friends on an adventure into deep space. 

Recommended for fans of sci-fi, especially grounded, near future sci-fi. But also for anyone who enjoys Chricton style adventures.

Sons and Lovers

A young man works through relationships with the women in his life.

This book lands right in the sweet spot for me. It's ahead of its time, so it's open and direct about the stuff that goes on in the lives of real people. But it's old enough that it's not burdened with all the goofy affectations of modernism.

The prose is strong, it's not shy about its subjects, and the characters are deeply and lovingly portrayed. It feels fresh, vibrant, authentic, and accessible even a century and change after it was written. I will never get tired of reading stories about people and their relationships.

Strongly recommended for all.

Peter Pan

The original adventure to Neverland.

I read the play hoping for surprises, but the old Disney movie does a faithful enough job that nothing stood out.

It‚Äôs an ecstatic fever dream of a story and Peter Pan is a timeless character.

Watch the cartoon and watch Hook. It‚Äôs more on brand for this content.

Grendel

A monster engages in a miserable, hyperactive intellectual inner life leading up to his encounter with Beowulf. 

I was expecting a more conventional story: ‚Äúhey this monster is actually just a well intentioned but misunderstood character!‚Äù

But Grendel is doubly a monster here. He still devours men and beasts, but he‚Äôs also an intellectual monster, almost exactly a French existentialist. 

I really despise those guys, but somehow the whole schtick seemed more palatable packaged this way. 

Making Grendel a sympathetic antihero is a mid tier achievement. Making existentialism tolerable is S tier. 

It‚Äôs an impressive book, but I wouldn‚Äôt recommend it. Narrow exception for those who are into both Beowulf and ambivalent about existential philosophy.

The Kreutzer Sonata

Misogynist recounts the story of killing his wife, delivering a polemic against desire along the way. 

This was hard to square with the Tolstoy I know and love. Part of me still feels like it must be tongue in cheek and that the anti-love, anti-marriage, anti-desire screed is put into the mouth of a wife killer to discredit it. 

I violated one of my firm guidelines and looked up Tolstoy‚Äôs stated position on the matter. Seems like he meant it sincerely as an argument for chastity, and that he really believed the straightforward statement of Pozdnyshev‚Äôs position.

Life is good. Love is good. Desire is good. This novella is bad. 

Not recommended for anyone.

Over Sea, Under Stone 

Three kids and their uncle pursue the grail in Cornwall.

This is the first of a series known collectively as The Dark is Rising. It‚Äôs less fantasy and more adventure than the rest. 

The writing is good, the story is good, it has layers for kids and adults. The connection to Arthurian legend gives it some nice British zest. My kids loved it. No complaints here. 

Recommended for reading to kids.

Pedro Paramo

A man in search of his father visits a ghost town that turns out to be substantially populated actual dead people.

I should have had a bigger reaction to this, given that I‚Äôm from the rust belt and I love books about death. The whole book is about the dead and dying in a declining Mexican village. 

But a big part of what I find so interesting about death is its awesome terrible finality. And this book presents death as a permeable barrier. The spirit world interacts extensively and fluidly with the real world. And the narrative is nonlinear, which emphasizes the muddling of the life and death border. 

Mostly it just made me crave another pass through 100 Years of Solitude. 

I tried reading this in Spanish but couldn‚Äôt hack it. It shook my confidence in my Spanish reading comprehension, but then I struggled to understand it in English, which reassured me a bit üòÖ

Only recommended if you‚Äôre addicted to magical realism and running low on supply.

The Cossacks

Young aristocrat moves to the sticks to live awhile with some tough frontier people. 

It‚Äôs a fun and exciting adventure, with all the usual Tolstoy depth and substance. My only complaint is that some of the philosophical tangents carry on long enough to disrupt the main narrative. 

The protagonist is mostly just a vehicle for the aforementioned philosophy and for introducing us to the Cossacks. The Cossacks are the stars of the show, and they form a memorable ensemble. I especially liked Eroshka. 

Read Anna Karenina and War and Peace first, but don‚Äôt overlook this book.

Redwall 

Game of Thrones meets The Wind in the Willows; a young mouse goes on a quest to find ancient arms then uses them to vanquish terrible foes. 

This is a book for kids. Adults should not read it on their own. But it‚Äôs probably better than a lot of the books you‚Äôll read this year.

The book opens with one of the all time great feasts, which the author probably justified to the editor as an important technique for establishing that Redwall Abbey is a place of peace and security for the community. But clearly it‚Äôs mostly just an expression of Jacques‚Äô exuberant and genuine love of food. 

Following hot on its heels, we meet Cluny the Scourge, leader of a horde of invaders and one of the book‚Äôs two great villains.

The hero Matthias seeks out the lost sword and shield of Martin the Warrior, the founder of Redwall Abbey. In the course of overcoming various obstacles, he meets and befriends the Sparra tribe and the Shrew tribe, and also slays Asmodeus, a giant magical snake monster. 

He returns to the Abbey with a full complement of gear and a new sense of his own capabilities, and leads the forces of good to victory. His mentor dies in the assault, but Matthias gets the girl and the two have a son. 

The story is timeless, the writing is good, the characters are quirky and lovable. The whole thing is incredibly well done. 

This is one of my boys‚Äô all time favorites and it‚Äôs one of the best kids‚Äô books I‚Äôve ever read. 

Highly recommended for 4-11 year olds.

Menu Design In America

Lots of gorgeous pictures of old menus with interesting writeups. 

Fun because the design is so good, the menus are so surprising, and the nostalgia is so potent. 

Highly recommended coffee table book.
